options: Raise the issue at the next practice meeting
Take no action as it is not a clinical matter
Discuss your concerns with your trainer
Speak to the relevant doctor directly
Contact the patients affected asking them to book in for reassessment
questions:
You are a GP registrar. During a placement you consistently see patients who have been given long sick notes by one of the locum doctors. For example a patient with a chest infection is given a 4 week note whilst another patient with depression is given a note for 4 months. You feel these are excessively long.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Whilst giving sick notes may not be considered a clinical matter it is a part of medical practice and constitutes a legal document. Sick notes that are too long are not only bad for society but may also be bad for the patient. It is, therefore, appropriate to act on your concerns.

As always, it is best to discuss this with the relevant person first. Discussing your concerns with the locum allows the doctor to give their 'side of the story' - it may be that you were not aware of the full circumstances regarding the patients concerned.

The next best response is to discuss the matter with your trainer. They may have their own concerns and are best placed to take appropriate action if necessary.

Raising the issue at the practice meeting will at least ensure that the issue is addressed but may come across as being confrontational.

As mentioned above, whilst the issuing of sick notes may be considered not a clinical matter it is an aspect of medical practice and hence a doctor should act if they are concerned.

Calling the patients in to reassess their need for sick notes is likely to reduce confidence in your colleague.

options: Refuse to discharge the patient
Discharge the patient following completion of her TTOs
Speak to your registrar regarding your concerns
Speak to your consultant about the decision to discharge and air your concerns
Speak to occupational therapy and physiotherapists about how she has been in sessions
questions:
You are a junior doctor on an orthopaedic ward. Mrs Jacobs, 72, is a lady who has been on the ward recovering from a fractured hip following a fall at home. Your consultant tells you to discharge the patient, however, you are of the opinion that she is not yet fully fit to discharge.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Speaking to your consultant and airing your concerns (4) over the patient's fitness for discharge is the most appropriate option. As a foundation year 1 doctor you will likely spend the most time on the ward and with the patients than any other member of the medical team. Therefore, if you have concerns regarding a patient then they should be discussed, despite you being the most newly qualified member of the team. A discussion with your consultant may in fact bring about a change in heart from your consultant, or ease your mind with regards to the discharge decision. Speaking to your registrar (3) is the next most appropriate option, however it is less preferable than option 4 as the overall decision ultimately lies with the consultant.

Speaking to occupational therapy and the physiotherapists about how the patient has been in sessions (5) is an important step to take and something that should definitely be done prior to discharge. However, voicing your concern over the discharge to members of the medical team is more appropriate as the decision to discharge ultimately lies with them.

Refusing to discharge the patient (1) is an inappropriate option as you have not discussed your reasonings for being concerned over this patient's discharge. Discussion is an important part of working within a team, and refusing to complete a task without explaining and discussing why is inappropriate. This, however, is better than discharging the patient (2), as in this option you have failed to bring your concerns to the attention of your colleagues and seniors, which may be of significant importance in the decision to discharge and the safety of the patient.

options: Phone the Clinical Director and explain the situation asking for advice
Accept her professional opinion and reassess the situation in 30 minutes
Set-up the NIV equipment yourself to avoid any further delay
As there is a disagreement on management speak to the consultant on-call
Ask the registrar on-call to review the patient and then speak to the physio themselves
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in medicine. Whilst on-call you review a 60-year-old woman who is known to have COPD. She has been admitted with an infective exacerbation and has not responded to nebulisers and intravenous aminophylline. Her most recent blood gases show a worsening respiratory acidosis. You feel that non-invasive ventilation (NIV) is needed and bleep the on-call physio. After discussing the blood gas results over the phone she says that NIV is not indicated in her opinion and refuses to set it up. You have not been formally trained to set up NIV yourself.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
As a ST1 doctor it would be appropriate to discuss the case with your registrar, especially if there is a disagreement among colleagues.

The next best option here is to speak to the consultant on-call. They have ultimate responsibility for the patient's care and should be informed if the on-call team are having difficulty managing the patient.

The Clinical Director of the hospital may be able to liaise between the different members of the health care team but the problem should be escalated within your own team first.

The physio may be experienced in providing NIV but it is ultimately a medical decision about whether to start a treatment.

Accepting her opinion is a poor option as she has not reviewed the patient herself and is only giving an opinion on the basis of blood gases.

Setting up NIV equipment requires training. If done incorrectly it could potentially harm a patient.

options: Accept the patient and ask the staff to transfer her to the medical assessment unit
Simply refuse in order to avoid the patient being admitted under an inappropriate specialty
Tell the surgical registrar that you will contact the on-call surgical consultant if he refuses to accept the patient
Go down to the emergency department and review the patient
Phone the surgical team yourself to discuss the matter
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in medicine doing a nightshift. An elderly patient with colorectal cancer has been admitted to the Emergency Department with suspected bowel obstruction. The Emergency Department F2 doctor has tried to refer the patient to the surgeons but was told that as no surgical intervention is likely the patient should be admitted to the medics. The F2 doctor therefore phones yourself and asks you to accept the patient.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Scenarios similar to this occur on an almost daily basis for admitting medical teams. The priority in all of this has to be the patient. It may be the case if the patient is end-stage then medical admission is more appropriate. If they are Duke's A and awaiting an operation then clearly they are surgical. Until you review the patient yourself you will not have all the facts and this is therefore the best option.

Discussing the matter with the surgical team will help to clarify their opinion about the patient and is the next best option. Accepting the patient without review risks placing a patient with an acute surgical problem on a medical ward. This may delay or compromise care.

Getting into an argument with the surgical registrar is not constructive and is a poor choice, as is simply refusing to see the patient as this indicates a disregard for the patient.

options: Always make sure the F1 doctor reviews the patient before you do, whenever you are bleeped by a nurse
Take no further action to prevent conflict in the team
Explain the situation and ask him what happened
Make the other middle-grade doctors aware of his attitude
Speak to his clinical supervisor
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in medicine. During an on-call you get bleeped by nurse asking you to review a patient who is coughing up blood. The nurse says she bleeped the F1 doctor but 'he told me to bleep you as he's busy and you'll have to see the patient anyway'. After reviewing the patient you go down to the doctor's mess to find the F1 doctor sat watching a film and eating a pizza.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This episode has demonstrated a poor attitude by the F1 doctor. It is however important to get his side of the story before taking matters further. If such behaviour continues then, apart from being annoying, it is interfering with his training as a junior doctor. His clinical supervisor should therefore be informed so that he/she may take steps to rectify the problem.

Gossiping to the other middle-grade doctors about the attitude of a F1 doctor is common and may be seen as a way to apply 'soft pressure' but it is not the most professional approach and may alienate the F1 doctor.

Insisting that he always sees the patient first is a poor response as it may be dangerous, particularly if he is called to see someone who is acutely unwell. As it endages patient safety it is therefore the worst response.

Call the consultant's secretary and leave a message

Email your educational supervisor
questions:
You are driving to work and get a puncture. You expect that you are going to be at least 2 hours late.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This question is about professionalism.

EXPLANATION
  • 3 - The best option is to speak to a member of your team directly as messages can often be missed
  • 2 - The consultant's secretary is an appropriate member of the team to contact but leaving a message is not the best option
  • 5 - Emailing your educational supervisor does let someone know you will be late but they are often not part of your team.
  • 1 - Not telling anyone is a bad option but does not cause others to be unprofessional
  • 4 - Asking the other F1 to lie is the worst option as it does not solve the problem and is unprofessional in 2 aspects

KEY POINTS
  • Professionalism
  • Team members

options: Do nothing
Document conversation and examination findings in the patient's notes
Give advice for shelters and domestic violence groups
Inform the police
Speak to her partner in the waiting room regarding her injuries and ask how they really happened
questions:
You are a ST1 doctor in the emergency department treating a woman with suspicious looking bruising, which she says was down to her falling down the stairs. On further questioning she reveals that her husband is physically abusive, but that she does not want anybody to find out and is happy to continue as things are. She tells you that her husband has never used weapons against her and there are no children in the household.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The main themes in this question are those of confidentiality, when you are able to break it and patient safety.

Option 3 is the best option in this question. Giving the patient advice for shelters and domestic violence groups is providing her with information about dealing with the issue, without breaking the patient's confidentiality. In this scenario the patient is able to make an informed decision regarding her well-being, as you have given her all the information she requires.

The next best thing to do is to document the conversation you have had with the patient (2). She may be happy with her home life currently, however documentation may be later required if she were to seek legal action against her husband. Furthermore, confidentiality has not been broken. It is for this reason that option 1 is listed on here before options 4 and 5. Although doing nothing does not sound like a preferable option, it is more appropriate than breaking confidentiality in this case.

GMC guidelines, with regards to when it is necessary/appropriate to break confidentiality says that:


'Disclosure of personal information about a patient without consent may be justified in the public interest if failure to disclose may expose others
to a risk of death or serious harm. You should still seek the patients consent to disclosure if practicable and consider any reasons given for refusal. Such a situation might arise, for example, when a disclosure would be likely to assist in the prevention, detection or prosecution of serious crime, 23 especially crimes against the person. When victims of violence refuse police assistance, disclosure may still be justified if others remain at risk, for example, from someone who is prepared to use weapons, or from domestic violence when children or others may be at risk.'

In this scenario the household does not contain any children and the husband has never used weapons against the patient. She has not given permission for you to inform the police or any other body, therefore confidentiality should not be broken in this case. Therefore, options 4 and 5 are the least appropriate options.

Informing the police (4), although inappropriate, is more appropriate than speaking to the patient's partner in the waiting room. Speaking to the patient's husband may result in verbal or physical aggression and may cause the husband to seek punishment/retribution for the patient informing staff of the domestic violence.

options: Ask her to limit visits or consider registering with another practice
Suggest she sees you once every 2 weeks for any similar muscle or joint pains
Have a conversation with the patient about her frequent attendance and suggest booking a regular appointment every two weeks initially
Suggest to the patient that her frequent attendance suggests you aren't getting anywhere and that she may be better seeing another GP
Take no action as mentioning her frequent visits may damage the doctor-patient relationship
questions:
You are a junior doctor in General Practice and have now been at the surgery for the past 8 months. A 57-year-old female patient comes to see you at least once a week, sometimes more often. She has a history of depression and fibromyalgia but has no other significant chronic disease. Typically she'll present with ongoing arthralgia, myalgia, low mood and pruritus. Despite extensive investigations, no underlying organic cause has been found for her symptoms. She is always polite and punctual.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This question looks at the management of a 'frequent-flyer'.

From the scenario, it appears that the patient has developed an element of doctor dependence. The best option is to be honest with the patient about your observations (C) and suggest a way of resolving the issue. One of the best approaches to this problem is to arrange regular appointments (B), the time between which can be gradually increased.

Taking no action (E) just means there is no improvement, for either the doctor or the patient.

Asking her to see another doctor (D) or register with another practice (A) is simply passing the issue on and is not in the best interests of the patient. It is sometimes easy to forget the amount of trust and respect some patients still have for doctors. Advising her to see another doctor may seem attractive if you find the consultations tiresome but is likely to be taken personally by the patient.

options: Phone the patient immediately to find the nature of the allergy and complete an entry in your e-portfolio
Phone the patient immediately to find the nature of the allergy
Do not contact the patient to prevent undue worry but complete a clinical incident form

questions:
At the end of the surgery you are writing up your notes. One of the patients you saw presented with a chest infection and you prescribed cefaclor. On looking at the notes though you can see he has a recorded allergy to penicillins, the nature of which is not known.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
There is approximately a 10% risk that a patient who is allergic to penicillin is also allergic to cephalosporins. For this reasons patients who've had an anaphylactic reaction to penicillins are advised to avoid cephalosporins. The nature of the previous reaction is not known in this scenario.

The most important step is to contact the patient immediately and make them aware of what has happened. If they have previously had an anaphylactic reaction to penicillin it is obviously important that they do not take the cefaclor. Regardless of what the patient says it is important to complete a clinical incident form. This is superior to an e-portfolio entry.

Failing to contact the patient is a poor option as it exposes them to risk.

options: Speak to the FY2 and request politely that he stops communicating the entries in the notes to the patient and relative
Go straight to the FY2's senior and inform them that what he is doing is out of line
Let the FY2 continue what he is doing
Explain to the relatives and patient that your team are the best point of contact for any information or questions that need addressing
Discuss the problem with your senior and ask if they will speak to the FY2
questions:
An FY2 from another ward knows one of your patients. He keeps coming up to your ward, reviewing their notes and relaying what has been written to the relatives and the patient.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Option A shows you are taking initiative and attempting to solve the problem yourself. Done politely, it should hopefully not hurt the FY2's feelings and will rectify the situation easily.

E is also a good option since your senior will also be more senior to the FY2 and may be better placed to deal with the situation. It is ranked lower than A because A shows that your are using initiative to try and solve the situation yourself.

D is ranked lower than A and E since it is not the family that are at fault here and they may get slightly offended at the indirect request to stop receiving information from the FY2.

B is an unfair option as this may be a situation that is easily solved by simply speaking to the FY2.

C is ranked lowest because this is impinging on patient confidentiality. The FY2 is not involved in the patients care and should therefore not be looking at confidential details about the patient.

C is ranked lowest because this is impinging on patient confidentiality. The FY2 is not involved in the patients care and should therefore not be looking at confidential details about the patient.
